intro.p: Exposes the effect script from Thomas Fuchs (http://script.aculo.us, http://mir.aculo.us)

section.title: Effects2Helper()
section.p: Initializes a new instance of the Castle.MonoRail.Framework.Helpers.Effects2Helper class.

section.title: InstallScripts() : String
section.p: Renders a Javascript library inside a single script tag.

section.title: Appear(String elementId) : String
section.p: Make an element appear. If the element was previously set to display:none; inside the style attribute of the element, the effect will automatically show the element.

note.p: Microsoft Internet Explorer can only set opacity on elements that have a 'layout'. To let an element have a layout, you must set some CSS positional properties, like 'width' or 'height'.

section.title: Fade(String elementId) : String
section.p: Makes an element fade away and takes it out of the document flow at the end of the effect by setting the CSS display property to false.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI). Microsoft Internet Explorer can only set opacity on elements that have a 'layout'. To let an element have a layout, you must set some CSS positional properties, like 'width' or 'height'.

section.title: Puff(String elementId) : String
section.p: Gives the illusion of the element puffing away (like a in a cloud of smoke).

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI).

section.title: DropOut(String elementId) : String
section.p: Makes the element drop and fade out at the same time.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI).

section.title: Shake(String elementId) : String
section.p: Moves the element slightly to the left, then to the right, repeatedly.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI).

section.title: SwitchOff(String elementId) : String
section.p: Gives the illusion of a TV-style switch off.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI).

section.title: BlindUp(String elementId) : String
section.p: This pair of effects simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements stay in place.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI), except table rows, table bodies and table heads.

section.title: BlindDown(String elementId) : String
section.p: This pair of effects simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements stay in place.

note.p: Works safely with most HTML block elements (like DIV and LI), except table rows, table bodies and table heads.

section.title: SlideUp(String elementId) : String
section.p: This pair of effects simulates a window blind, where the contents of the affected elements scroll up and down accordingly.

note.p:
You must include a second DIV element, wrapping the contents of the outer DIV. So, if you call new Effect.SlideDown('x'), your element must look like this:
contents
Because of a bug in Internet Explorer 6 (overflow not correctly hidden), an additional wrapper div is needed if you want to use these effects on absolutely positionend elements (wrapper is the absolutely positioned element, x has position:relative; set; ):
contents
Works only on block elements.
